i am setting up a lab of thin clients
but they cant boot from the network
so the instructions say to put something on the HD that will pull it over the network.. so
you shouldn't have to resort to using dd
if your hardware supports BOOTP, that's much easier.  Sometimes you need extra firmware on the NICs for bootp
or support in the BIOS
the thing with dd is a hack for machines that don't really support network boot
the thing is, any tiny detail will make that sort of hack not work
and unless you are good at the network bit level or have a hardware ethernet analyzer (or both), there isn't a lot you can do
